Adam,

Well,  I don't have Sandy's awesome recipe for Chicken soup, I tend to
cheat and buy it out of a can! :) But I do hope that you are feeling
better soon. And don't worry, I am sure the game came wait for a while
longer. The land of make-believe should ALWAYS take a back-seat to the
real one. :)

P.S. Sandy, I may have to try the recipe myself :)

- Preston



On 10/20/11, Sandy <magicquartz@...> wrote:
> I hope you feel better soon.  I just made a block buster chicken soup from
> scratch to bring to my friend's mom who was also  not feeling well.  And if
> you have someone to make it for you, here's what you do.
>
> Ingredients:  One whole chicken, three to four onions, a handful of parsley,
> five of six carrots, several stalks of celery, and a pinch of salt,
> according to your taste.
>
> Put the whole chicken in a large soup pot, and pour just enough water over
> the chicken to cover it.  Then add onions, carrots, celery and then season
> with salt according to your own taste.  Start the soup on high until it
> begins to boil, then lower to a slow to steady simmer for two to three hours
> or until the legs of the chicken are loose.  * Just lift the chicken out of
> the pot with a pair of tongs and jiggle the legs* .  Once the legs are
> loose, you're ready to take the meat and veggies out of the soup.  First
> discard the parsley, which is only there for flavor, then in a sparate
> mixing bowl, you add the veggies and on a platter you put the chicken.
> Allow meat and veggies to cool and then start by cutting the veggies into
> bite sized pieces and put them back into the broth of the soup.  Then you
> take the chicken off the bones, discard skin, fat and bones, and shred the
> meat into bite sized pieces and put that back into the soup.  Once this is
> done, turn off the heat and allow the soup to cool. Once it cools down the
> fat will rise to the top and it will solidify.  When you're ready to eat it,
> just skim the top of the soup and remove the fat.  Heat to desired
> temperature slowly and boil up your favorite pasta and most importantly,
> ENJOY.
>
> This is our family recipe that comes straight from Florence, Italy.  Trust
> me, you'll love it.
>
> --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, "adamsafran" <adamsafran@...> wrote:
>>
>> OOC - Sorry for the lack of posting, running a fever and so I fear I won't
>> be super active until it passes.  Thanks for understanding!
>>
>
>
>
